hololive night Collaboration Event Returns to Dodger Stadium on July 5th, 2025! | NEWS | hololive official website - „Éõ„É≠„É©„Ç§„ÉñÂÖ¨Âºè„Çµ„Ç§„Éà
hololive night Collaboration Event Returns to Dodger Stadium on July 5th, 2025!
item.author: Horii
item.content:encoded: June 9, 2025, Tokyo, JAPAN ‚Äî COVER Corporation (Minato-ku, Tokyo, Japan, CEO: Motoaki Tanigo) announced the second collaboration between the Los Angeles Dodgers and hololive production, taking place on Saturday, July 5th, 2025, at 4:15 PM (PDT).After a successful first collaboration with the Los Angeles Dodgers last year, ‚Äúhololive night‚Äù will return to Dodgers Stadium again a second time. This year‚Äôs collaboration will feature the first-ever VTuber livestream both to and from Dodger Stadium. To furthermore commemorate this unique evening, co-branded Dodgers x hololive production merchandise will be available to purchase in the gift shops across the stadium.Fans can expect exclusive in-stadium appearances from three hololive English talents, Ninomae Ina‚Äônis, IRyS and Koseki Bijou in real time. The hololive talents will not only cheer for the Dodgers, but also provide their sing-along version of ‚ÄúTake Me Out to the Ball Game‚Äù during the seventh-inning stretch of the baseball game. At the end of the game, fans will be invited to join the talents on the field, where they will host special programming such as interactive activities, and a new ‚ÄúWHO‚ÄôS got the MOVES?!?!‚Äù segment where fans can dance and jam together to popular hololive tunes. In addition, this special event will be broadcast live to hololive English‚Äôs official YouTube channel, marking the first time ever in history for a VTuber company to stream both to and from Dodger Stadium. Fans can also enjoy a vast series of onsite hololive-themed activities, such as taking pictures with the featured talent‚Äôs cutouts, helping themselves to delicious stadium food and drinks with event-only hololive themed packaging, and more to be announced via hololive English‚Äôs official social media channels later.The hololive night ticket package includes a ticket to baseball game as well as event-exclusive Dodger x hololive production trading cards (pack of three) that feature the three main cast of this year‚Äôs event in Dodgers uniforms. Lucky fans may even draw a special version of the cards that include the talent‚Äôs printed autograph!Get hyped with us for this exciting collaboration between the Los Angeles Dodgers and hololive production! We hope to see you at the game.Official Hashtag: #hololiveDodgers„Éª ‚ÄúPlay Ball!‚Äù Announcement „Éª ‚ÄúTake Me Out to The Ball Game‚Äù Sing-a-long „Éª Photo Spot with Life-size Cutouts „Éª Event-Only Food & Beverage Packaging „Éª holodance Crowd Dance Project „Éª First-ever VTuber Livestream from the Stadium ‚Ä¶ and MORE!Collaboration Merchandise(*Products under development)Available from July 5th, 2025 in all shops inside Dodger Stadium. *While supplies last!On July 5th at Dodger Stadium, special beer, soda, and popcorn cups will be offered in hololive collaboration packaging. Please enjoy these special collaboration designs, which can only be enjoyed during hololive night.hololive night Ticket Informationhololive night Ticket Purchase Bonus: Special Trading Cards (pack of three)For the first time in history, a VTuber livestream will be held at and from Dodger Stadium. The livestream will be available on YouTube, allowing people from all over the world to experience the thrill of the event in real time. „Éª Dance Project ‚ÄúWHO‚ÄôS got the MOVES?!?!‚Äù The livestream will feature a dance project segment taking place at Dodger Stadium. Songs by hololive production talents will be played at the stadium, and those who want to try their hand at the choreography will dance together! The song selection will be announced later on hololive production‚Äôs official social media.The stream will also feature other surprises from hololive production, including past videos, so be sure to tune in! Despite her looks, Ina‚Äônis is actually a priestess of the Ancient Ones. One day, she picked up a strange book and then started to gain the power of controlling tentacles. To her, tentacles are just a part in her ordinary life; it has never been a big deal for her. However, her girly mind does want to get them dressed up and stay pretty. After gaining power, she started hearing Ancient Whispers and Revelations. Hence, she began her VTuber activities to deliver random sanity checks on humanity, as an ordinary girl. A Nephilim who was once the embodiment of hope back in ‚ÄúThe Paradise‚Äù. While she has left to set off on an adventure, she continues to deliver hope through her lyrics and songs, with determination in her voice. She also bears the precarious and unstable dual nature of a half-demon and half-angel; this phenomenon can be observed on rare occasions, in the form of the most unpredictably yaba‚Äî*ahem*, ‚Äúsurprising‚Äù, comments from IRyS herself. Bewildering those around her is but another unexpected charm of her duality. Formed from the crystallization of all forms of human emotion, Koseki Bijou is ‚ÄúThe Jewel of Emotions.‚Äù Over years and years, emotions of beauty and filth alike have woven into her under immense pressure, resulting in an unmatched brilliance. Her ancient, mystic brilliance caused strife between the masses of the greedy, who fought over ownership of her. This led to her being imprisoned in secrecy, far from the reach of humans. It seems as though when she encounters people, and particularly their good emotions, her radiance shines even brighter.

2025Âπ¥8Êúà16Êó•(Âúü)ÔΩû17Êó•(Êó•)10:30ÔΩû„Äê‰ºÅÊ•≠„Éñ„Éº„Çπ„Äë„Éõ„É≠„É©„Ç§„Éñ„Éó„É≠„ÉÄ„ÇØ„Ç∑„Éß„É≥Ôºè„Ç´„Éê„ÉºÊ†™Âºè‰ºöÁ§æ„ÄåÁôæÂπ¥Ê¢ÖÈÖí„Å∫„Åì„Çâver.„Äç„ÄåÈÖî„ÅÜ„Åü„ÅÑÁÑº„Åç„Åï„Åè„Çâ„Åø„Åì„Åô„Å∫„Åó„ÇÉ„Çã„ÄçÔºà„Ç≥„Éü„Ç±ÊúüÈñìÂ§ñ„Åß„ÇÇË≥ºÂÖ•ÂèØËÉΩÔºâÔ∏é„Åù„ÅÆ‰ªñ„ÅÆË≥ºÂÖ•„É´„Éº„Éà„Ç≠„É£„É©„ÇØ„Çø„Éº„Éá„Ç∂„Ç§„Éä„ÉºÔºàÈÄöÁß∞„Éû„Éû„Å®Âëº„Å∞„Çå„ÇãÊñπ„ÇÑ„Éá„Ç∂„Ç§„É≥„Å´Êê∫„Çè„Å£„ÅüÊñπÔºâ„ÅÆ„Çπ„Éö„Éº„Çπ‰∏ÄË¶ß„Åß„Åô„ÄÇ‚ÄªÈ†íÂ∏ÉÁâ©„ÅØ„ÅÆÊâ±„ÅÑ„Åß„Åô„ÄÇÂÖ¨Âºè„Ç∞„ÉÉ„Ç∫„Åß„ÅØ„ÅÇ„Çä„Åæ„Åõ„Çì„ÄÇ‚ÄªÁ©∫Ê¨Ñ„ÅØÂèÇÂä†„ÅÆÊúâÁÑ°„Åå„Çè„Åã„Çâ„Å™„ÅÑÁä∂ÊÖã„Åß„Åô„ÄÇ‚Äª„Éõ„É≠„É©„Ç§„ÉñÈñ¢ÈÄ£„ÅÆÈ†íÂ∏É„Åå„Å™„ÅÑÂ†¥Âêà„ÇÇ„Çπ„Éö„Éº„ÇπNo.„ÇíË®òËºâ„Åó„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇÈ†íÂ∏ÉÂÜÖÂÆπ„ÅØ„ÅîËá™Ë∫´„Åß„ÅîÁ¢∫Ë™ç„Åè„Å†„Åï„ÅÑ„ÄÇ‚ÄªË®òÂÖ•Êºè„Çå„ÉªÈñìÈÅï„ÅÑ„ÇÑÂ§âÊõ¥‰∫ãÈ†Ö„Åå„ÅÇ„Çä„Åæ„Åó„Åü„Çâ„Åì„Å°„Çâ„Å´„ÅîÈÄ£Áµ°„ÅÑ„Åü„Å†„Åë„Çã„Å®Âä©„Åã„Çä„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ„Ç≥„Éü„ÉÉ„ÇØ„Éû„Éº„Ç±„ÉÉ„Éà„Å´ÂÖ•Â†¥„Åô„Çã„Å´„ÅØ„Äå„Äç„Åæ„Åü„ÅØ„Äå„Äç„ÅåÂøÖË¶Å„Åß„Åô„ÄÇÔºà‰∫ãÂâçË≤©Â£≤„ÉªÂΩìÊó•Ë≤©Â£≤Âà∂Ôºâ‰∏ÄËà¨ÂÖ•Â†¥„Åô„Çã‰∫∫Âêë„ÅëÔºàÊäΩÈÅ∏Âà∂ÔºâÈñãÂ†¥Áõ¥Âæå„Å´ÂÖ•Â†¥„Åó„Åü„ÅÑ‰∫∫Âêë„Åë„ÉÅ„Ç±„ÉÉ„ÉàÔºàÊäΩÈÅ∏Âà∂ÔºâÈñãÂ†¥Áõ¥Âæå„Åã„ÇâÊõ¥Ë°£ÂÆ§„Çí‰Ωø„ÅÑ„Åü„ÅÑ‰∫∫Âêë„Åë„ÉÅ„Ç±„ÉÉ„Éà„ÉÅ„Ç±„ÉÉ„Éà„ÅØÂêçÂâç„ÅåÂç∞Â≠ó„Åï„Çå„ÄÅÂΩìÊó•Êú¨‰∫∫Á¢∫Ë™çÊõ∏È°û„ÅåÂøÖË¶Å„Åß„Åô„ÄÇËª¢Â£≤ÂìÅ„Åß„ÅØÂÖ•Â†¥„Åß„Åç„Åæ„Åõ„Çì„ÅÆ„ÅßË≤©Â£≤„ÉªË≥ºÂÖ•„ÅØ„Åó„Å™„ÅÑ„Çà„ÅÜ„Å´„Åó„Åæ„Åó„Çá„ÅÜ„ÄÇ‚Äª„Äå„Ç¢„Éº„É™„ÉºÂÖ•Â†¥„Äç„Éª„ÄåÊõ¥Ë°£ÂÆ§ÂÖàË°åÂÖ•Â†¥„Äç„ÅØ‰ºöÂ†¥„ÅßÂèó‰ªòÊôÇ„Å´„É™„Çπ„Éà„Éê„É≥„ÉâÂûãÂèÇÂä†Ë®º„Å∏‰∫§Êèõ„Åô„ÇãÂøÖË¶Å„ÅÇ„Çä„ÄÇ‚ÄªË¶™Â≠ê„ÅßÂÖ•Â†¥„Åô„ÇãÂ†¥Âêà„ÅÆ„Åø„ÄÅ„ÉÅ„Ç±„ÉÉ„Éà„Éª„É™„Çπ„Éà„Éê„É≥„Éâ1„Å§„Å´„Å§„Åç‰∏≠Â≠¶Áîü‰ª•‰∏ã1‰∫∫Âêå‰º¥ÂèØËÉΩ„ÄÇ„Åü„Å†„Åó‰∏≠Â≠¶Áîü‰ª•‰∏ã„Åå‰∏Ä‰∫∫„ÅßÂèÇÂä†„Åô„ÇãÂ†¥Âêà„ÅØ„É™„Çπ„Éà„Éê„É≥„ÉâÂûãÂèÇÂä†Ë®º„ÅåÂøÖË¶Å„ÄÇ1Êó•ÁõÆÂçàÂæåÔºè2Êó•ÁõÆÂçàÂæåÔ∏éÂÖ•Â†¥ÈñãÂßãÔºöÔºüÔºüÔºüÔ∏é‰æ°Ê†ºÔºöÔºüÔºüÂÜÜ‚ÄªË¶™Â≠ê„ÅßÂÖ•Â†¥„Åô„ÇãÂ†¥Âêà„ÅÆ„Åø„ÄÅ„ÉÅ„Ç±„ÉÉ„Éà„Éª„É™„Çπ„Éà„Éê„É≥„Éâ1„Å§„Å´„Å§„Åç‰∏≠Â≠¶Áîü‰ª•‰∏ã1‰∫∫Âêå‰º¥ÂèØËÉΩ„ÄÇ„Åü„Å†„Åó‰∏≠Â≠¶Áîü‰ª•‰∏ã„Åå‰∏Ä‰∫∫„ÅßÂèÇÂä†„Åô„ÇãÂ†¥Âêà„ÅØ„É™„Çπ„Éà„Éê„É≥„ÉâÂûãÂèÇÂä†Ë®º„ÅåÂøÖË¶Å„ÄÇ„Çµ„Éº„ÇØ„É´ÂÜÖÂÆπ„ÅØ„Åô„Åπ„Å¶„Ç´„Çø„É≠„Ç∞„Å´ÈõÜÁ¥Ñ„Åï„Çå„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇÁèæÂú®„ item.title: Here‚Äôs a Super Cute Hololive Idle Game. It‚Äôs Out on Steam Today. Go Nuts - VICE
Cultivating Your Hardcore VTuber Audience
item.author: Thomas Toblu
item.content:encoded: Being a female VTuber ‚Äì whether you‚Äôre an indie streamer or part of a corp like Hololive English ‚Äì means tapping into a passionate fandom. Some fans are just casual viewers, but the (‚Äúgachi-koi,‚Äù ‚Äúunicorns,‚Äù etc.) make or break a VTuber‚Äôs career. These super-devoted fans invest time, money, and emotion in you . Understanding who they are (and who casual viewers are) is the first step.A is made of viewers who treat your avatar and persona almost like a beloved idol. They form ‚Äì one-sided bonds where fans feel close to you even though you only interact through the screen.. Hardcore fans come in flavors: (heavy ‚Äúin-love‚Äù supporters) and fans. Gachikoi are the ultimate super-fans: they buy every merch, subscribe, member, and tip just to support you ‚Äì basically your virtual ‚Äúboyfriend/girlfriend,‚Äù showering you with money and praise Unicorn fans, by contrast, are totally into your . They demand (Cute Girls Doing Cute Things) ‚Äì think solo or all-girl collabs ‚Äì and don‚Äôt care about your off-screen life. They‚Äôll quit your channel if you invite male collabs, but otherwise they just love every adorable thing you do. Both types are highly parasocial ‚Äì they feel like your best friends (or lovers), even though you only know them through the stream .In short, a hardcore audience is . They will subscribe, join paid memberships, buy merch, draw fan art, organize Discord communities, and defend you online. Casual viewers might stop by for a stream or two, but hardcore fans stick around and actively fuel your channel. As VTuber Sensei puts it, ‚ÄúCasual fans might stop by‚Ä¶ but hardcore fans are the ones who stick around and invest their time, money, and emotional energy‚Äù. Those hardcore fans keep you relevant in a crowded market, and VTubers who nurture them enjoy long-term success even when casual viewership dips.Idol Culture and VTuber FandomVTubers didn‚Äôt emerge in a vacuum ‚Äì they grew from , and that cultural heritage shapes fandom expectations. In J-pop idol culture, fans often expect their idols to stay ‚Äúpure,‚Äù forming one-sided romantic feelings and even demanding a ‚Äúno-dating‚Äù image. VTubing inherited this model in some ways. Like traditional idols, VTubers present carefully crafted personas: colorful avatars and consistent characters that never break character in public. This approach lets fans project feelings onto you. Parasocial relationships are at the heart of this: viewers feel a unique closeness because they can chat with you live, send donations, and even see your avatar react in real time . This direct interaction takes idol culture‚Äôs ‚ÄúIdol Journey‚Äù ‚Äì where fans support an idol‚Äôs growth ‚Äì and turbocharges it with technology.Because of this idol influence, many VTuber fans come with very specific expectations. They want you to be cute, supportive, and accessible, but also mysterious. They crave : they‚Äôll remember your catchphrases, avatar details, inside jokes ‚Äì and expect the same personality each time. This can lead to pressure: some hardcore fans (especially unicorns) even that their fave VTuber not interact with male streamers, mirroring old idol rules . On the positive side, idol culture also means fans will go all-out supporting you ‚Äì buying albums (read: music CDs), concert tickets (3D live events), and tons of merch. The Hololive 3D live concerts are a perfect example: fans passionately cheer and spend just like idol concert-goers.Idol culture‚Äôs key legacy is . Fans develop an ‚ÄúIdol Journey‚Äù bond: they follow you from debut onward, cheering as you improve (level up your streaming, celebrate milestones, drop music, etc.). The more you lean into that persona-driven, interactive style, the more you encourage that idol-like loyalty. As Vtuber Sensei notes, VTubers and idols share a powerful phenomenon: a ‚Äúspecial and strong parasocial relationship‚Äù where fans feel personally connected to the avatar. This closeness fuels both the emotional satisfaction of fans and their willingness to on you (time, money, clout).Why Hardcore Fans Matter: Economics and EmotionHardcore fans are literally the of a VTuber‚Äôs career ‚Äì financially and emotionally. Economically, the VTuber world thrives on fan spending. VTuber streams only bring in modest ad revenue unless you‚Äôre huge, so most income comes from fans: superchats/donations, memberships, sponsorships, merch, and live events Hardcore fans pay for all of it. They‚Äôll subscribe or join multiple tiers of memberships (often 5$‚Äì30$/month) because it‚Äôs like joining your ‚Äúfan club‚Äù ‚Äì and 70‚Äì80% of that is your profit. They‚Äôll also drop big Super Chats (with YouTube taking 30%), send tips, and buy merchandise even at high prices. In fact, VTubers make up seven of the top ten most Superchatted channels on YouTube, showing how aggressively fans tip their favorites. According to industry data, merchandising is exploding: Cover Corp (Hololive‚Äôs parent) saw nearly 80% growth in merch sales in one quarter, thanks to fans buying everything from official card games to limited-edition hoodies. (Those fans are hardcore!)Even beyond money, hardcore fans are an emotional pillar. They form communities ‚Äì Discord servers, Reddit groups, fan art boards ‚Äì that keep your brand alive between streams. They constantly share clips, hype up events, and defend you from trolls. Psychologically, VTubers offer fans . Many viewers are socially isolated young men; watching your stream gives them a sense of companionship and a ‚Äúsafe space‚Äù to interact. When you thank someone by name, laugh at their jokes, or remember their pet‚Äôs name, it fulfills a real human need. Hardcore fans often report feeling happier and less lonely after watching their favorite VTuber. This emotional bond makes them fiercely protective: they‚Äôll rally behind you during tough times and celebrate your victories as their own.Crucially, VTubers who nurture hardcore fans tend to thrive long-term. These fans keep watching and supporting even if algorithms change or casual viewer counts dip. ‚ÄúThe loyalty these hardcore fans provide is essential to the long-term success of any VTuber‚Äù. In lean times, these die-hards are the ones still clicking ‚Äúlive,‚Äù still dropping the odd Super Chat, still repping your merch. They basically pay your bills ‚Äì or at least bankroll the majority of your income. Vtuber Sensei bluntly advises: cherish those hardcore fans, because ‚Äúthey will carry you through your VTubing journey‚Äù.Casual vs Hardcore Viewers: How They Impact Your ChannelNot all viewers are equal. Understanding vs. is key to growing and sustaining your community: They catch a stream when they can, maybe watch an interesting game, or tune in during a big event or collaboration. They rarely stick around for the full stream and will drop off early if something better comes up. They might follow your highlights on YouTube or social media, but they don‚Äôt tune in regularly. At best, some casual fans will subscribe or join the lowest membership tier only to get a few extra perks, but they or buy merch. These viewers boost your raw view count, but they‚Äôre unlikely to leave comments, tip a lot, or build community. You can‚Äôt rely on casuals for steady revenue ‚Äì in fact, Vtuber Sensei notes you ‚Äúrarely [make] a living off‚Äù a purely casual audience unless you have the backing of a big agency. A special subset of casuals ‚Äì they appear for big events (like collabs or announcements) and vanish otherwise. They might contribute a like but never engage deeply or donate. These give spikes in viewership statistics, but don‚Äôt build your core fanbase.Hardcore (High-Value) Viewers: These are the Gachikoi and Unicorns we described. They watch every stream they can, often for hours on end. They engage in chat, donate superchats on occasion, and subscribe to memberships (sometimes multiple tiers). They also help set trends ‚Äì streaming cons told by clips and fan works. In forums and social media, they praise you and defend you if someone trolls you. These fans directly boost important metrics: high concurrent viewer counts, longer average watch times, and active chat logs help with platform algorithms. In short, hardcore fans are far more per person than casuals.The impact on your channel shows up in two ways: Casuals give you random spikes, but hardcore viewers give you consistency. A stream with mostly hardcore fans might have a smaller peak, but steady viewership and high engagement (like chat activity or superchats throughout). This consistent support makes your channel look healthier to platforms. Over time, hardcore fans also help you trend ‚Äì they share clips and fan content, bringing in new eyes. Hardcore fans pay for memberships, merch, and donations, whereas casuals rarely do. For example, a VTuber membership (fan club) can cost the equivalent of $5‚Äì$30 a month, which adds up when dozens or hundreds of hardcore fans join. Merchandise sales (T-shirts, keychains, plushies with your avatar) only happen when fans are in you. Casuals might buy a sticker, but hardcore fans will buy you release. A strong core of super-fans thus keeps the bank account healthy even if occasional viewers trickle.In short: casual viewers grow numbers; hardcore fans grow longevity. A massive but shallow audience can flame out; a modest but dedicated fanbase can sustain a career Hololive English Case StudiesHololive English (HoloEN) provides real-world examples of how cultivating a hardcore audience pays off. The first generation (Gawr Gura, Mori Calliope, Takanashi Kiara, Ninomae Ina‚Äônis, Watson Amelia) each built fiercely loyal followings with distinct brands. Gura leaned into her shark-theme and cheeky personality, focusing on gaming and singing streams. Fans (her self-named ‚ÄúChumbuds‚Äù and ‚ÄúShrimps‚Äù) adopted her catchphrases, fan art, and even fan-made songs. She hit millions of subs in record time, illustrating how a clear niche plus consistent persona attracts both casual viewers hardcore fans. The around Gura (shark loli, memes) spread virally on Twitter/Reddit, showing hardcore fan involvement.Mori Calliope (Dead Beats): As Hololive‚Äôs musical emcee, Mori focused on original music. Her fans eagerly bought her albums and merch whenever released, treating each song drop like an idol single. Calliope‚Äôs emphasis on songwriting and character lore gave fans deep content to engage with. Her dedicated music supporters famously streamed her songs en masse (some hits reached millions of views in hours), exemplifying how tailored content and community hype fuel success.Cover Corp‚Äôs financial reports reflect this engagement. For example, Cover reported a ~50% revenue jump in one quarter, attributing much of it to new VTuber debuts (bringing new fanbases) and merch sales up nearly 80% thanks to fan demand. These numbers wouldn‚Äôt exist without super-fans snapping up products and promoting the brand.(Note: Hololive is a prime example of corporate strategy. But many independent female VTubers apply the same principles. Nimi Nightmare, for instance with a majority of male fans, leans heavily on GFE interaction to nurture those fans. Independent VTubers often rely even more on core fans since they lack corporate marketing, so they mirror these idol tactics in how they engage and brand themselves.)Actionable Strategies: Attracting and Nurturing Your Core FansBuilding a hardcore audience takes deliberate effort. Here are concrete steps VTubers can use to attract, retain, and grow a loyal fanbase, rooted in community-proven tactics:Craft a Clear Persona & Niche: Know who you are and stick to it. Successful VTubers have a consistent character and theme. Maybe you‚Äôre the gentle ASMR storyteller, the over-the-top gamer, or the soothing 2D musician. Pick what makes you unique. Gawr Gura focused on her shark motif and love of games/music, and that clear branding helped her fans ‚Äúget‚Äù her instantly. Your hardcore fans will rally around whatever distinctive trait or niche you own.Be Authentic and Responsive (Parasocial Bonding): Hardcore fans thrive on feeling close to you. During streams, , react to comments, and remember repeated viewers . Even small gestures make a big difference: a quick shoutout to ‚ÄúSuzuki-san‚Äù or remembering a regular viewer‚Äôs birthday makes them feel . Fans often say this personal touch is what makes them tune in every time. In short, treat your chat as friends. Be warm, caring, or playful ‚Äì whatever fits your persona ‚Äì and keep it consistent. One useful tactic is membership- or subscriber-only streams: e.g. a Q&A for subs or a private Discord hangout. This keeps interactions for your core fans, deepening the bond without requiring 1-on-1 chats with every fan (setting a healthy boundary). Ironically, maintaining mystery can make fans appreciate you more. You want to be engaging , but you don‚Äôt have to be on-call 24/7. Politely manage messages/DMs: for instance, direct fans to fan servers or use bots to handle routine stuff. This way, you stay safe from harassment but also make your live appearances feel more special. VTuber Sensei reminds creators to ‚Äúset boundaries‚Äîboth in what you share and how you respond to over-familiar fans‚Äù. Clear rules (e.g. no private social media DMs, no sharing personal info) protect you and remind fans that interactions happen mostly on stream. This actually preserves the idol aura many fans expect. Keep your visuals and voice . Use the same avatar style and catchphrases on YouTube, Twitter, TikTok, etc. Hardcore fans notice if your persona wavers. If you‚Äôre a gentle story-teller, keep that vibe even on Instagram. If you‚Äôre the goofy gamer, meme-hard on Twitter too. Consistency helps fans feel at home and spreads your identity: for example, Gura‚Äôs shark theme and Mori‚Äôs oni horns are instantly recognizable and used in memes and fan art. Also use platform features: update your Twitch panels with your logo colors, have a unique clap-emote on YouTube, etc. All this solidifies your brand and keeps fans engaged.Engage in Fan Communities: Join (or start) Discords, subreddits, Twitter hashtags, etc. Fan communities often flourish on their own, but your presence (even silently reading or occasionally dropping a message) shows you care. Fanart channels, meme channels, translation channels ‚Äì encourage them. When fans create fan art or fan songs, shout them out or react on stream. For example, when Mori‚Äôs fanmade music videos popped up, she publicly thanked the creators, which only fueled more creativity. This user-generated content keeps your fandom active. Also, consider contests or streaming games with fan-donated ideas. This co-creation makes fans feel invested in success. Offer memberships and merch that hardcore fans love. Create with genuine perks: special emotes, access to a private Discord voice chat on stream nights, or an exclusive monthly hangout stream . Make the perks feel like ‚Äújoining your inner circle.‚Äù For merch, start with simple things fans can wear or display: T-shirts, hoodies, phone cases, stickers with your avatar or catchphrase. Then consider big-ticket items: plushies, figures, or artwork prints. Limited drops and themed bundles (e.g. ‚ÄúFirst Anniversary Set‚Äù or ‚ÄúGame Tournament Hoodies‚Äù) create excitement. Hardcore fans buy merchandise to and feel closer to you 6768. (Sales of merch are a stream because once it‚Äôs made, fans buy repeatedly.)Exclusive & Behind-the-Scenes Content: Hardcore fans crave anything . This can be easy to implement. Do occasional where you maybe try a new project or just hang out in low-key chats. Release behind-the-scenes clips on Patreon or YouTube membership only ‚Äì things like your VTuber rig setup, avatar design process, or blooper reels. The feeling of an ‚Äúinner circle‚Äù is priceless to fans. It says, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre more than a number; you‚Äôre a supporter who gets special access.‚Äù VTuber Sensei recommends, ‚Äúoffer your hardcore fans something special, like exclusive streams‚Ä¶ or behind-the-scenes content. Make them feel like part of an inner circle‚Äù. In the VTuber world, collabs can boost exposure. But to keep hardcore fans happy, pick your collabs . Many unicorn fans don‚Äôt like collabs with male streamers ‚Äì so if that‚Äôs your audience, you might want to prioritize all-female collabs or VTuber-only collabs. (Alternatively, handle it on stream: if you do a mixed-gender collab, reassure fans it‚Äôs just professional content and you‚Äôre not changing your persona. But expect a hit in revenue.) Likewise, collaborating with fans (fan artists, voice actors) can be a fun way to reward community members. But don‚Äôt spread collabs too thin ‚Äì fans sometimes feel betrayed if you suddenly stream with a random creator unrelated to your theme. Balance broadening your network with keeping your core brand. Hardcore fans often keep calendars to watch streams. Maintaining a consistent streaming schedule helps them plan around your content. If fans know you‚Äôre live every Tuesday/Friday at 7pm, they‚Äôll regularly show up. Sudden cancellations or long hiatuses can lose momentum. Of course, life happens ‚Äì but give as much notice as possible and perhaps do a shorter backup stream or a quick chat so they aren‚Äôt left hanging. Ultimately, none of the above matters if the content doesn‚Äôt . Play games or do activities you genuinely enjoy (this keeps energy up), but also pay attention to what hardcore fans love: maybe chatty ‚ÄúJust Chatting‚Äù nights for bonding, or themed streams (karaoke nights, ASMR, storytelling, etc.) that fit your character. Analyze which streams get the most engagement or donations and do more of those. Variety is good, but a core identity (idol, artist, gamer, etc.) is key. High production values (good audio, visuals) also signal you care ‚Äì and in our avatars, even minor improvements (like a cool new wave effect when someone subs) can thrill fans.Handle Shoppers (Gachikoi) and Shippers Carefully: Some hardcore fans (gachikoi) might act overly possessive, shipping you with someone or demanding personal attention. Engage gently: thank them for support, but keep public comments professional. If a fan tries to force personal drama (‚ÄúWhy aren‚Äôt you dating so-and-so?‚Äù), it‚Äôs okay to politely ignore or set boundary. High-conflict drama can upset other fans, so manage it swiftly. However, don‚Äôt alienate them completely ‚Äì they still spend a lot on you. Redirect their passion: for example, start a fan art contest instead of a ‚Äúship‚Äù rumor.Embrace the Parasocial (But Carefully): Remember, hardcore fans feeling they have a personal connection. Use parasocial techniques: use warm language like a friend, share ‚Äúpersonal‚Äù stories through your character (e.g. funny pet anecdotes, favorite foods), even role-play ‚Äúfield trips.‚Äù Just keep real personal details vague to maintain healthy boundaries. For example, talk about your day as if you‚Äôre with them ‚Äúlate night studying‚Äù or ‚Äúcooking dinner.‚Äù This closeness makes fans feel they truly know you, boosting loyalty. But at the same time, don‚Äôt pretend too realistically ‚Äì maintain character cues so fans remember it‚Äôs an avatar. It‚Äôs a balancing act between fantasy and authenticity.Marketing Savvy (VTuber Marketing): Even as a VTuber, some marketing thinking helps. Use SEO keywords in your video titles (‚ÄúVTuber audience,‚Äù ‚Äúparasocial relationship,‚Äù etc.) if that‚Äôs part of your strategy. But more importantly, engage fans on social media like a brand: post clips on TikTok or Twitter, run polls (‚ÄúWhat song should I cover next?‚Äù), and use fan-friendly hashtags. Announce merch or events with tease images. Some VTubers create countdowns or small puzzles leading up to big streams ‚Äì these gamify your content. All these strategies are part of VTuber marketing: building hype and staying top-of-mind for your core fans. As one VTuber guide notes, ‚ÄúIf your target audience is fans who want more than just casual chats, you‚Äôll use your persona and consistent messaging to attract them‚Äù. Show appreciation. Thank your member sub-hype trains on stream, post a ‚Äúthank you‚Äù tweet after hitting a goal, or send a fan a surprise gift (like a hand-signed art print) as a raffle prize. When fans feel recognized, they dig in even deeper. Many VTubers hold loyalty badges (e.g. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve been a member for 6 months!‚Äù) or special titles for long-time followers. These small rewards keep hardcore fans around.The Takeaway: Make Hardcore Fans Your FoundationIn the fast-moving VTuber world, chasing every trend or viewer gimmick leads nowhere. The are your foundation. They pay the bills, build the hype, and emotionally support you. Idol culture taught us that a passionate dedicated fanbase can turn a new face into a superstar. VTubers just have to tap into that by providing consistent, authentic content and fostering real connections.As VTuber Sensei puts it: ‚ÄúHardcore fans are the backbone of any successful VTuber brand. They buy your merch, show up to streams no matter what, and spread the word about you‚Äù. In other words, treat them like VIPs. Offer them exclusives, involve them in your journey, and always stay true to the persona they love. If you do that, you‚Äôll find those casual lurkers may slowly transform into your next super-fans.Remember: a parasocial relationship might only be ‚Äúone-sided,‚Äù but its rewards can be very real. Your hardcore audience isn‚Äôt just a number on a dashboard ‚Äì they‚Äôre a community that gives to your VTuber career. So engage honestly, brand smartly, and always appreciate the Chumbuds, Shrimps, and Nincompees by name. They‚Äôll repay you with loyalty, revenue, and the joy of watching your character thrive.

item.title: Transcending Age and Language: hololive SUPER EXPO 2025 Attendee Interviews
item.author: cover_yamaguchi
item.content:encoded: Kids Influencing Parents: Enjoying hololive as a FamilyA mother of a son in the 2nd grade of junior high school visiting from Hokkaido prints stickers at the Magical Girl holoWitches! booth as she enjoys EXPO with her son and husband as a family. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm here with my son because he‚Äôs a fan. We try to watch streams together as a family when we have the time,‚Äù she told us. Her son also went on to say, ‚ÄúMy oshis are Usada Pekora and Murasaki Shion. I became a fan of hololive because of a smartphone game collab they did.‚ÄùThey explained that they have experienced going to a movie theater in Hokkaido in the past for a live viewing, but this time they planned to go to the live concert the following day, which was going to be their first time watching a hololive performance live, so they were really looking forward to it. The son has a lot of merchandise in his room, and told us that hololive for him is one of the ‚Äújoys in life.‚ÄùWe also spoke to an uncle-niece duo from Saitama who were enjoying some of the EXPO-exclusive food who told us that they ‚Äúbecame fans of hololive from watching YouTube Shorts.‚Äù The man continued, ‚ÄúI realised that my niece was also a fan when she bought hololive wafers,‚Äù and that EXPO 2025 was the first event they had attended.¬†He went on to say that, ‚Äúhololive is so comforting for me,‚Äù and his niece also expressed her love for hololive music and the trading card game (TCG): ‚ÄúMy favorite song is Captain Houshou Marine‚Äôs ‚ÄúBishoujyo Muzai‚ô°Pirates. I have also played in a hOCG tournament before.‚Äù She continued telling us her dreams: ‚ÄúI want to be a VTuber in the future. I‚Äôm designing characters with my school friend,‚Äù and when asked about why hololive is so appealing, she responded from the genuine perspective of a schoolchild, ‚ÄúEveryone is so fun and are like friends to me.‚ÄùWe Learned How to Sew! Hobbies and Community Through hololiveWhen asked about their thoughts on EXPO, three friends in their 20s from Chiba and Tokyo who had come in hololive Indonesia 1st Generation cosplay said, ‚ÄúWe had been looking forward to our oshis‚Äô food! Moona-chan‚Äôs (Moona Hoshinova) Nasi Goreng came with a postcard and it tasted really good!‚ÄùThe girls, who arrived at the event at 6:30 AM on the first train of the day, had started making their costumes a month prior. ‚ÄúWe bought all the material separately to suit our costumes.‚Äù they told us. ‚ÄúWhen COVID-19 hit, we couldn‚Äôt go outside so we started watching streams, which was something we were still able to enjoy without leaving the house,‚Äù they replied when asked about how they got into hololive. They were also addicted to hololive Indonesia content as a part of that.¬†They also talked about overcoming language barriers and communicating across borders: ‚ÄúWe couldn‚Äôt understand Indonesian at all in the beginning, but gradually started picking it up. Even now, we are looking up things in Indonesian, and interacting with Indonesian fans as well.‚Äù‚Äúhololive is one of our joys in life; we live for it. We usually wake up watching hololive and fall asleep to it too. It‚Äôs always there by our side regardless of whether we‚Äôre sad or happy.‚ÄùThey even gained new hobbies: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve even learned how to sew thanks to cosplaying.‚ÄùTwo self-professed otaku friends in their 20s came from Osaka and Tokyo to attend both days of EXPO. They told us that they planned to cosplay on the second day as Houshou Marine in costumes that they made by hand together. ‚ÄúWe were originally VTuber fans, and then got into hololive through watching 3rd Generation video shorts. We‚Äôll definitely be going to our oshi‚Äôs live concerts now!‚Äù said the hololive fans of four years.‚ÄúThe Magical Girl holoWitches! booth was really good. We were really moved by the costumes there,‚Äù they responded about EXPO 2025.Their passion for hololive was evident as they spoke: ‚ÄúWe watch our oshis every day: streams on our commutes and when we‚Äôre getting ready. We put on archived content, and it always feels like they‚Äôre with us. hololive is our lifeline‚Äîwe couldn‚Äôt survive without it.‚ÄùAnother fan of 3-4 years in their 40s hailing from Tokyo was with plushies of his oshi Tsunomaki Watame he had brought, enjoying an EXPO-exclusive drink. He told us that he had arrived at 7 in the morning and ‚Äúwas glad to see the mascot parade, something that [he doesn‚Äôt] normally get to see.‚ÄùHe spoke about the appeal of hololive: ‚ÄúIt is what comforts me on a daily basis.‚Äù‚ÄúWhen I recommend hololive to people, I tell them that there are so many different kinds of VTubers, so they can definitely find one that suits them.‚ÄùHe was at EXPO with two of his friends who gained another common interest thanks to hololive: ‚ÄúThey are longtime friends of mine who became fans of hololive because of my recommendations.‚Äùhololive Transcending Borders: From Online Encounters to Real-Life FriendshipsA fan of 5 years in his 30s who had traveled to Japan all the way from the Netherlands spoke about his love of cosplaying: ‚ÄúI really wanted to cosplay today, but I couldn‚Äôt get a ticket.‚Äù‚ÄúI have been cosplaying for over half of my life,‚Äù he asserted, stating that he had started cosplaying when he was 17. ‚ÄúI was really looking forward to the hololive English booth (ENigmatic Recollection). I‚Äôm so glad I was able to see the booth where all the members are together for the first time.‚ÄùA HOLOSTARS fan in her 20s who had traveled from Kanagawa talked to us about her oshis Rikka, Hanasaki Miyabi and Minase Rio and how she came across hololive production: ‚ÄúI started getting into them through watching their live content on TikTok about 2-3 years ago.‚Äù‚ÄúI was originally a fan of other streamers, but HOLOSTARS was the reason I became interested in VTubers,‚Äù she said, also mentioning that she has a channel membership on YouTube.Four Oozora Subaru fans who met on social media (one of whom was in Japan from South Korea) told us that ‚Äú[they] occasionally meet offline!‚ÄùThe one from South Korea also went on to say, ‚ÄúI first came across hololive at the start of 2022. Even in South Korea, there are events and collab cafes, and there‚Äôs even a live viewing for today‚Äôs event (EXPO).‚ÄùThey also told us from each of their perspectives what hololive means to the four of them: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a place that gives us energy.‚Äù‚ÄúI get energized from Subaru-chan‚Äôs (Oozora Subaru) streams.‚Äù‚ÄúIt‚Äôs entertainment that makes you feel positive.‚Äù‚ÄúI feel really close with them because we see not only how they are on regular streams, but who they are in daily life too.‚Äù‚ÄúThere‚Äôs so much content in the archive that you can never get sick of it.‚ÄùEXPO: The Culmination of Diverse Connections Made Through hololiveWe heard from people from all walks of life through these interviews over the two days at hololive SUPER EXPO 2025 Supported By BANDAI/hololive 6th fes. Color Rise Harmony at Makuhari Messe, showcasing how hololive can be enjoyed by anyone regardless of age, gender or nationality, and connects people through fan interaction. Whether you are a school student, adult, family, friends with a common interest or by yourself, hololive is a place for everyone to enjoy in their own way.We also heard how much hololive production means to people, with answers like ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs part of my daily life,‚Äù ‚ÄúI live for hololive,‚Äù and ‚Äúhololive comforts me,‚Äù giving us a little insight into how hololive is more than just a mere hobby for some.¬†¬†Stay tuned here on COVERedge for more on the constant evolution of hololive production, bringing fans together regardless of talent and fan relationships.¬†(Please also check out interviews with staff and booth representatives about the booths that featured at EXPO 2025 in Parts 1 and 2.)

item.title: Inside the hololive OFFICIAL CARD GAME: COVER and Bushiroad Share Untold Stories and their Vision for the Future
item.author: cover_yamaguchi
item.content:encoded: I started by buying various card games in Akihabara and studying them. At the time, I was also acting as manager of the commercialization team, so from launch to release, it felt like I was just constantly running full steam ahead. Honestly, those days were such a whirlwind that I barely even remember them‚Ä¶(lol)I started working with Kawatsu in March 2024 and I clearly remember being asked, ‚ÄúHow many people are working with you?‚Äù and answering, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just me.‚Äù¬† Every time I explained the situation, so many people told me, ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs insane!‚Äù (lol). Nevertheless, it was thanks to the support of my colleagues in other departments and collaborators such as Kawatsu that we were able to reach the point where the game was ready for release. I also felt I could draw on my own personal childhood memories of playing card games, which helped me a lot through this process.

Apart from a selection of official hololive production merchandise, exclusive content will also be available.The hololive production official shop in Osaka Umeda offers an abundance of attractive content, so don‚Äôt miss this chance to visit us.Shop NameÔºö hololive production official shop in Osaka Umeda LocationÔºöOsaka 1-1-3 Shibata, Kita-ku, Osaka 530-0012„ÄÄHANKYU SANBAN GAI Kita-kan B1F DatesÔºö Friday, June 27th, 2025 to Spring 2026 Operating hoursÔºö 10AM ‚Äì 9PM* Same as the operating hours for HANKYU SANBAN GAI.As we expect a surge of visitors , we will limit entries using LivePocket-Ticket-. Please register from the application pages below.Dates of restricted entriesAdditionally, we will be restricting entry and handing out numbered tickets should there be a high number of customers aside from the aforementioned dates.Store-original merchandise will be available in advance. * There may be purchase limitations due to limited stock. * We will try to ensure there are sufficient stocks, but please understand that they may still sell out. * We cannot answer inventory-related inquiries (available quantities, restock dates, etc.). * We will be selling merchandise from this store post this event. * Images are for illustrative purposes only. Actual products may differ.Featured Talents for Part One Shirakami Fubuki / Nakiri Ayame / Houshou Marine / Shishiro Botan / Kikirara Vivi „Éª New arrivals of store-original merchandise „Éª A selection of merchandise from the hololive production OFFICIAL SHOP * „Éª A selection of licensed merchandise from hololive production* The lineup will not include talent anniversary or made-to-order merchandise. Once sold out, some merchandise may no longer be available.Novelties will differ depending on the period and amount purchased. We will gift novelties on a first-come, first-served basis when you purchase over a certain amount in-store.* Randomized novelties will not be able to be chosen and will only be available while stocks last.Novelty giveaway periodÔºö From Sunday, June 27th, 2025, while stocks last. „Éª Every 3,300 yen (tax incl.) spent in a single purchase will entitle customers to one hololive production official shop in Osaka Umeda original Vol.1 Uchiwa (handheld fan) (5 Designs/Randomized) „Éª Single purchases over 11,000 yen (tax incl.) will entitle customers to one hololive production official shop in Osaka Umeda original bag (1 type)In addition, any customers who show staff that they have registered for an account on the holoplus app will receive an additional novelty. Download holoplus* All novelties are available while stocks last.We will continue to provide more exciting content for everyone who visits us at the HANKYU SANBAN GAI, so be sure to stay updated for the latest news.‚ë† Life-sized illustrated panels of the talents as shop staff displayed outside the store For a limited time, life-sized panels of talents as shop staff will be displayed in HANKYU SANBAN GAI. WhenÔºö Friday, June 27th ‚Äì Friday, July 25th, 2025 (Illustrated by ‰∏â‰πùÂëÇ)‚ë° Mini-character illustration of talents as shop staff displayed by the escalator in front of the store Mini-character illustration of talents as a shop staff will appear in the open area inside HANKYU SANBAN GAI.‚ë¢ In-store special announcements Apart from original in-store announcements by the five featured talents, you will also get to hear announcements from hololive production‚Äôs official anchorwoman, Harusaki Nodoka.‚ë£ A message from the talents The store will feature autographs and messages written by the featured talents.

item.title: Special Talk from Former Weekly Shonen Jump Editor-in-Chief, Mr. Kazuhiko Torishima
item.author: Âπ≥ÊùæÊ¢®Ê≤ô
item.content:encoded: On May 17, 2025, we held a special in-house talk featuring Mr. Kazuhiko Torishima, former Editor-in-Chief of at SHUEISHA Inc., who played a key role in bringing numerous hit titles such as and to life. Drawing from his experience working alongside some of the industry‚Äôs top creators, Mr. Kazuhiko Toshima shared his valuable perspective on creative collaboration and what it takes to shape true compelling entertainment.During the session, Mr. Kazuhiko Torishima shared the story behind the launch of Weekly Shonen Jump and spoke in detail about the three core principles that have shaped the magazine‚Äôs enduring success: giving opportunities to new talent, fostering a collaborative relationship between editors and creators, and making sure that reader feedback is valued most. The two-hour session ‚Äì including a Q&A portion ‚Äì covered a wide range of topics from behind-the-scenes insights into the manga creation process using actual panel and page layouts, to a thought-provoking look at how social media and smartphone culture has influenced modern manga.¬†The session received enthusiastic feedback from employees, with many commenting that they were able to reflect on the talk through the lens of their own work and reaffirmed the importance of communication. It proved a valuable opportunity for all participants to broaden their perspective and deepen their understanding of what it means to create and collaborate within the entertainment industry.It was a meaningful and enriching opportunity for employees working toward our mission ‚ÄúTogether, Let‚Äôs Create Culture Loved by All‚Äù and deeply connected to the values we strive to uphold in our day-to-day work.

item.title: hololive production 2nd World Tour Concert ‚Äúhololive STAGE World Tour‚Äô25 -Synchronize!-‚Äù Key Visual, New Cities, New Guests, and Merchandise Announcement
item.author: Horii
item.content:encoded: COVER Corporation (Minato-ku, Tokyo; CEO: Motoaki Tanigo) is pleased to announce the key visual, new cities, special guests, and merchandise for the second world tour concert, ‚Äúhololive STAGE World Tour‚Äô25 -Synchronize!‚Äù.The key visual for ‚Äúhololive STAGE World Tour‚Äô25 -Synchronize!‚Äù has now been unveiled. It features Momosuzu Nene, Kureiji Ollie, Mori Calliope, IRyS, and Nerissa Ravencroft dressed in stylish costumes. Additional information on special guests has also been released. First, Fuwawa Abyssgard and Mococo Abyssgard of hololive English -Advent- will be special guests at the Vancouver show. Akai Haato and Natsuiro Matsuri of the hololive 1st generation will appear at the New York show. Stay tuned for more information about guests at upcoming shows.Two cities that have been newly added to the world tour have also been revealed. The first is Seoul. This will be the first time hololive production performs a 3D concert there. The second is Taipei. Taipei was on the world tour last year and will be again this year. More information about the Seoul and Taipei concert dates and venues will be announced at a later date.An original theme song for the world tour is currently in the works. It will be sung by Momosuzu Nene, Kureiji Ollie, Mori Calliope, IRyS, and Nerissa Ravencroft. Please look forward to its release!

item.title: Makeship and hololive production Announce Adorable New Plushie Collection Featuring hololive English -Advent-!
item.author: Horii
item.content:encoded: COVER Corporation (Minato-ku, Tokyo; CEO: Tanigo Motoaki) announced today the release of the MAKESHIP x hololive English -Advent- exclusive plush collection, featuring members of hololive English -Advent-.The collection of plushies featuring the five captivating members of hololive English -Advent-: Nerissa Ravencroft, Shiori Novella, Koseki Bijou, and the twin hounds Fuwawa Abyssgard and Mococo Abyssgard.Following the overwhelming support for previous hololive production and Makeship collaborations, this new project will allow fans worldwide to bring home their very own cuddly companions inspired by the unique personalities and iconic designs of hololive English -Advent- members. Each plushie has been crafted to capture the lovely relationships between each member and their mascots.The plushie campaign will run for a limited time. Visit the Makeship website during the campaign to pre-order your favorite hololive English -Advent- members plushies and help bring this exciting project to life. Get ready, adventurers!MAKESHIP x hololive English -Promise- Plushie Collection Makeship is a platform that empowers creators and communities to bring their unique ideas to life through limited-edition physical products, primarily plushies. By utilizing a crowdfunding model, Makeship ensures that only successfully funded projects are produced, fostering a direct connection between creators and their fans.

item.title: The Rise of Indie VTubers Amid Corporate Agency Turmoil
item.author: Thomas Toblu
item.content:encoded: The VTubing phenomenon has exploded from a niche Asian curiosity into a global streaming powerhouse over the past decade. In 2016, the avatar Kizuna AI became a viral sensation, hitting 2 million YouTube subscribers in just ten months (konvoy.vc). Within a year (mid-2018), the active VTuber population doubled from about 2,000 to 4,000(konvoy.vc). By January 2020 there were over VTubers worldwide (konvoy.vc), and VTuber viewership swelled rapidly during the 2020 pandemic boom. Indeed, at one point VTubers accounted for 38% of YouTube‚Äôs top 300 highest-earning channels (114 of 300) with roughly total revenue (konvoy.vc).As demand surged, professional agencies sprang up. Japan‚Äôs Cover Corp launched in 2017, quickly building a stable of pro talent. Virtually at the same time, ANYCOLOR (then Ichikara) debuted , and Western-oriented agencies like appeared by 2020. By 2023 the two largest agencies alone boasted staggering followings ‚Äì subscribers for NIJISANJI and for Hololive (investing.com). And indie creators have thrived too. The VTuber market as a whole was already worth billions: one estimate put the global VTuber industry at , projected to (zionmarketresearch.com). (Another analysis cites $3.3B in 2023 and predicts ~$45.8B by 2032 ().)The past few years saw record growth. StreamsCharts data for 2024 Q1‚ÄìQ3 (below) shows VTuber watch-hours climbing from ~430 million in Q1 to ~440M in Q2 ‚Äì roughly a (streamscharts.com). In Q3, however, hours dipped slightly to ~433M (a 1.5% quarterly drop (streamscharts.com), the first decline after six straight growth-quarters.The chart above illustrates the trend: after years of explosive growth, VTuber viewership is now stabilizing. Even so, totals remain far higher than pre-pandemic; and VTubers continue to occupy a growing share of overall streaming. According to Stream Hatchet, VTubers now command 3.7% of live-stream viewership (up 10√ó from five years earlier) (). This mainstreaming means big brand partnerships and mainstream media exposure for VTubers ‚Äì but it also invites scrutiny of the corporate models behind them.Corporate vs. Independent VTubing: Pros and ConsIn the VTuber world today there are : corporate (or ‚Äúagency‚Äù) talents vs. independent (or ‚Äúindie‚Äù) creators. Each has distinct advantages and drawbacks:Agency (Corporate) VTuber: Signing with a talent agency like Hololive, NIJISANJI, or VShojo often grants an enormous head start. Agencies provide high-end resources ‚Äúto elevate your content‚Äù: pro avatar design, technical support, and marketing (vtubersensei.com). Talents get custom 2D/3D models crafted by experienced artists, polished overlays, editors, and even direction for content (vtubersensei.com). Importantly, agencies also bring instant exposure: a slot in a top agency means your debut is introduced to an existing fanbase, and you‚Äôll frequently collab with star classmates. Agencies handle promotion, sponsorships, and cross-channel events that an independent could never engineer alone (vtubersensei.com). In short, joining a well-known agency can give a huge jump in audience and production quality with far less effort on the part of the VTuber (vtubersensei.com).: All that support comes at a price. VTubers in agencies typically sign long-term, exclusive contracts with many restrictions. They often lose creative control: certain games or topics might be off-limits, and even collaborations or sponsorships may need agency approval (vtubersensei.com). Agencies may enforce strict quotas (e.g. required streaming hours), and because the persona/avatar is usually , leaving the company often means abandoning that identity (vtubersensei.com). In practice, this means if a talent parts ways, they typically cannot take their character or channel with them ‚Äì the IP stays with the company. Additionally, agencies take a share of revenue (sometimes 30‚Äì50% or more) (vtubersensei.com), meaning VTubers earn than they would independently. Some also report that agencies‚Äô bureaucratic structures and red tape can slow things down ‚Äì for example, one journalist noted complaints of and ‚Äúlimited creative freedom‚Äù among Hololive staff (virtualsweet.jp).: Going solo gives a VTuber full autonomy. An indie can stream any content they want, manage their own schedule, and keep essentially (minus platform fees) (vtubersensei.com). There are no corporate bosses or contracts limiting what you say or do, and you own all the IP for your character. Indies can pivot quickly or try unconventional ideas without waiting for approval. In many cases, this means greater creative satisfaction and control. For example, ex-agency talents have turned loose outside the corporate structure and invented new personas or content approaches that wouldn‚Äôt have been allowed on a corporate stream (hololivetoday.com)(jaxon.gg). In theory, indies have ‚Äúa higher degree of freedom‚Äù (as one analysis notes) and can connect more personally with fans as individual creators (news.viverse.com).: Of course, independents must handle . They must finance their own avatar and studio costs, learn editing and marketing, and build audiences from scratch (or rely on an existing fanbase). Without an agency team, technical glitches or business negotiations can fall entirely on the VTuber‚Äôs shoulders. Indies also often lack consistent production: many solo creators upload less frequently and may experience burnout when handling all roles. A common metaphor is that agency VTubers are like ‚Äúoffice workers‚Äù with support staff, whereas indies are solo entrepreneurs or artists (news.viverse.com). Crucially, breaking through as a completely new indie creator is very difficult. The vast majority of indie VTubers remain small or part-time; only a very few achieve large-scale success. This ‚Äúwinner-take-all‚Äù effect means that while headline success stories (often ex-agency talents) grab the limelight, indies build modest channels that never rival agency peers. As one analysis points out, the roughly one-third market share held by indies is ‚Äúlikely accounted [for] by a select group of successful indies,‚Äù implying that the average independent creator has a tiny slice (hololivetoday.com).In summary, agencies offer a with expensive production and built-in fans (vtubersensei.com), but at the cost of autonomy and revenue share(vtubersensei.com). Independent VTubers sacrifice that safety net for creative freedom and profit potential, but they face a steep climb to grow an audience on their own. The choice depends on a talent‚Äôs priorities: many aspiring VTubers join agencies for support, while others prize the indie path to keep their character and vision fully theirs (vtubersensei.com).Major Graduations and ExitsIn recent years, several high-profile VTubers have ‚Äúgraduated‚Äù or left their agencies, dramatically illustrating the tension between corporate control and personal freedom. These exits have drawn enormous fan attention and reshaped the scene. Below are some key examples:: In late 2024, Hololive English‚Äôs star announced she would graduate (leave Hololive) effective January 3, 2025. Fauna, one of the most-watched English talents, surprisingly cited ‚Äúdifferences in opinions with management‚Äù as her reason (vchavcha.com). Hololive‚Äôs official statement even explicitly used the term ‚ÄúGraduation‚Äù (implying a permanent departure in contrast to ‚ÄúAffiliation‚Äù). Many saw this as hinting at creative disagreements or stress. Within hours of her final Hololive stream, eagle-eyed fans noticed Fauna‚Äôs original persona ‚ÄúLemonLeaf‚Äù returning to activity: her YouTube channel rebranded as the day after her graduation (jaxon.gg) (virtualyoutuber.fandom.com). Nimi Nightmare debuted Jan 17, 2025 ‚Äì and blew past 300K subs almost immediately. In fact, her growth was meteoric: by Jan 18 she had 400K subs and by Jan 23 reached (virtualyoutuber.fandom.com). By late April 2025 she hit subscribers, with debut streams peaking over 90,000 viewers (virtualyoutuber.fandom.com). This spectacular surge shows Fauna‚Äôs fans loyally following her to indie status. (Notably, Fauna also announced she‚Äôd make all her past membership content free after graduation (vchavcha.com) ‚Äì a sign she wanted a fresh start.)Selen Tatsuki (NIJISANJI EN): Selen‚Äôs exit from ANYCOLOR‚Äôs English branch in January 2024 caused an uproar. The sudden of Selen‚Äôs contract (not a normal graduation) was officially attributed to ‚Äúbehavior unbecoming‚Äù (later rumors blamed social media incidents), but it happened just as she took a medical break, which sparked outrage. Fans and VTubers reacted with , accusing Nijisanji of mistreating talent (polygon.com). ANYCOLOR‚Äôs CEO later apologized for communication failures, but the damage to trust was palpable. Importantly, Selen immediately revived as indie persona: . In Feb 2024 she relaunched as Dokibird, and the fan response was staggering. On Feb 5, 2024, her YouTube subs jumped from ~9K to over , and one day later she hit (virtualyoutuber.fandom.com). Her debut stream on Feb 7 peaked at ~127,000 concurrent viewers. By Feb 13 she reached subs ‚Äì adding nearly followers in 8 days (virtualyoutuber.fandom.com). By mid-March she was over 600K subs and hosting huge charity streams. In short, Selen/Dokibird‚Äôs meteoric indie success ‚Äì and the vitriol aimed at ANYCOLOR over her firing ‚Äì became a turning point. Many in the community lamented that a beloved VTuber was driven out by rigid corporate rules, yet immediately flourished independently (polygon.com (virtualyoutuber.fandom.com).Pomu Rainpuff (NIJISANJI EN): Pomu was an original member of Nijisanji EN‚Äôs first generation . By August 2023 she had amassed over on YouTube (jaxon.gg) and seemed destined for big stardom. Then, in January 2024, Pomu announced a sudden graduation from Nijisanji EN citing burnout and . The news shocked fans; Pomu herself lamented that she had to turn down exciting projects due to agency constraints (though she said little publicly). Nearly three months later, in April 2024, Pomu re-emerged ‚Äì but this time as her original indie avatar ‚ÄúMint Fant√¥me (Maid Mint)‚Äù. As an indie, she immediately drew her old fans: within weeks she reached around (jaxon.gg), and by April 2025 she had about subscribers (her numbers are still growing) (businessinsider.com). While Maid Mint‚Äôs count is smaller than Pomu‚Äôs peak, it shows a devoted following. Pomu/Maid Mint‚Äôs story is unusual in that she went from indie ‚Üí corporate ‚Üí indie, and yet maintained a sizable audience. Many fans cheered her return as Maid Mint, seeing it as a ‚Äúsecond chance‚Äù at streaming on her own terms.: Gawr Gura, one of Hololive‚Äôs celebrated talents and the single-most-subscribed VTuber in the world ((over 4.5 million subs (essential-japan.com)), stunned the community in April 2025 by announcing her graduation effective May 1. The reason given was familiar: ‚Äúdifferences with management and the direction of the company‚Äù(essential-japan.com). The news was met with heartbreak and speculation. In a twist echoing Fauna, just days after her last Hololive stream, fans discovered Gura‚Äôs new independent channel. Now rebranded as , her debut video quickly confirmed the speculation ‚Äì and her audience reacted at warp speed. Within 24 hours, Sameko Saba‚Äôs YouTube and Twitter followed count exploded to jaxon.gg) (remember, that‚Äôs from near-zero overnight!). This makes Gura the latest example of a top VTuber successfully migrating to indie status without losing fan support. Cover Corp has emphasized that it still owns the ‚ÄúGawr Gura‚Äù character, so the new persona has a different name and look, but the loyal fanbase nearly instantly crossed over (jaxon.gg).Each of these graduations ‚Äì Fauna, Selen, Pomu, Gura ‚Äì sent shockwaves through the VTuber fandom. Fan reaction was overwhelmingly supportive of the talent. Social media exploded with messages like ‚ÄúI‚Äôm loyal to my oshi (favorite), not the company (hololivetoday.com). Viewers overwhelmingly took the side of the VTuber, trusting her narrative over the agency‚Äôs. Crowdfunding efforts like charity streams by Dokibird (raising $250K+) showed fans rallying to help the talent succeed. The common sentiment was that the content and personality of the individual, not the corporate label, were the real draw.In many cases, ex-corporate VTubers have indeed thrived independently, backed by these fans. Both Dokibird and Nimi Nightmare hit half a million subscribers within days/weeks of debuting. Maid Mint found over 300K as an indie. Gura‚Äôs Sameko is at ~200K after just a day. These stars have already shown they can monetize directly: for example, Dokibird‚Äôs February 9 ‚ÄúMerch Launch‚Äù stream generated nearly in YouTube superchats and tips (virtualyoutuber.fandom.com) ‚Äì more than she ever got as an agency talent in the same time span. Fauna‚Äôs merchandise sold out instantly. In short, the indie paths of these former corpo talents have been validated by the market: their audiences followed them and even expanded.At the same time, it remains an open question whether completely new VTubers (with no corporate pedigree) can break out at a similar level. So far, the most successful independents are often veterans or have compelling niches. Even Filian, one of the biggest ‚ÄúKojinzei‚Äù VTubers mentioned by Forbes, ironically joined a small agency in 2023, blurring the lines (news.viverse.com). Generally, analysts note that the indie viewership pie is dominated by the same ‚Äúsuperstar‚Äù phenomenon: a few big names get the lion‚Äôs share of views (hololivetoday.com). Fresh faces will need something truly unique to garner mass appeal without an agency‚Äôs marketing engine. It‚Äôs still early, but the expectation in the community is that fan loyalty will follow personalities ‚Äì so a crafty and charismatic new indie might still grow large, just as Dokibird did. But they will be entering a more competitive and saturated market.Industry Statistics: Viewership, Graduation Rates, and RevenueTo understand these trends, it helps to look at the data. Third-party trackers and market analysts have documented how VTuber viewership and business metrics are evolving: StreamsCharts reports that over the past few quarters, VTuber audience growth has plateaued. After reaching record watch-hours in late 2023 and early 2024, the numbers leveled off. VTubers still command hundreds of millions of hours watched per quarter; Q3 2024 had about watched (streamscharts.com) (vs. 440M in Q2). By one analysis, live-stream viewership attributable to VTubers has grown 10√ó over 5 years (), indicating explosive long-term growth, but short-term quarterly figures are now flat or even slightly down. Unique active VTuber channels fell below 5,000 in Q3 2024 (streamscharts.com), reflecting some consolidation.Agency vs Indie Market Share: Analysts estimate indies consistently hold around 35‚Äì36% of total VTuber watch-time. StreamsCharts pie-charts for Q3 2024 show independents at about , compared to Hololive‚Äôs ~23.5% and Nijisanji‚Äôs 18.9% (streamscharts.com). (Other agencies like VShojo, accelerators, etc., fill out the rest.) Hololive Today‚Äôs analysis similarly notes that independents have been stable at ~36% of viewership across recent quarters (hololivetoday.com). In other words, while the top agencies are still large, indies now represent over one-third of the VTuber audience by watch-time. This split is unusual: most entertainment niches are far more concentrated. It underscores that the VTuber audience is fragmented and that no single agency fully dominates.Graduation and Turnover Rates: Exact industry-wide figures are hard to come by, but 2024 saw unusually high turnover. ANYCOLOR closed its Indonesian and Indian NIJISANJI branches in 2023 and terminated several international talents. Cover also had multiple graduations and some suspensions. These high-profile exits (Fauna, Ame, Mumei, Gura, plus others like Hololive JP member Chloe, Aqua and Shion) have alarmed fans. For a sense of scale: NIJISANJI EN‚Äôs watch-hours fell by in December 2024 (reddit.com) (partly due to losing talents and halting debuts), while NIJISANJI JP‚Äôs hours grew. StreamsCharts even noted that in late 2024, Nijisanji EN was by far the worst-performing branch of ANYCOLOR, leading to speculation about merging it back into the main company. Despite short-term turbulence, the VTuber industry remains highly lucrative. In 2020, the top 300 YouTube channels that year made ~$26M from VTubers (konvoy.vc). Aggregate market research suggests in global VTuber revenue. As noted, Zion Market Research estimated ~$6.3B market value in 2023 (zionmarketresearch.com). (Other sources cite smaller or larger numbers, but all agree on a large, fast-growing market.) Much of this revenue comes from fan support: in the VTuber model, donations/superchats and merchandise sales form the bulk of income. For example, Kiryu Coco once earned ~$800K via superchats in a year (konvoy.vc). The new breakout indies are already pulling huge donation totals: Dokibird raised $252K for charity in early 2024 (virtualyoutuber.fandom.com), and Nimi Nightmare set a VTuber record by raising $361K in one charity stream (virtualyoutuber.fandom.com). These figures illustrate that fans are willing to directly finance independent VTubers just as they did with agency stars. The fortunes of VTuber agencies themselves have reflected these controversies. Both ANYCOLOR and Cover Corp (Hololive‚Äôs parent) are public companies in Japan, so their stock prices respond to news. For instance, ANYCOLOR‚Äôs shares in the weeks following Selen Tatsuki‚Äôs termination and other setbacks (investing.com). An analyst report noted that fans ‚Äúaccused [ANYCOLOR] of mistreating its rising talent‚Äù and pointed out the company‚Äôs repeated abrupt restructuring (closing whole country branches) (investing.com). Cover Corp has weathered more stable growth, but even it has faced scrutiny. In early 2024, Cover publicized that it had taken legal action in against fans/critics (cover-corp.com), which some observers worried could hurt its image.Cover‚Äôs latest financial reportControversies Undermining Agency TrustThe shift toward indies is closely tied to a series of scandals and trust issues at the big agencies. Fans have grown increasingly aware of behind-the-scenes problems:Abrupt Terminations and Non-Transparent Graduations: Agencies sometimes cite vague reasons for cutting ties. Fans were outraged by how arbitrarily Hololive or NIJISANJI jettisoned talent in 2024 and 2025. For example, both Fauna and Gura ‚Äúgraduated‚Äù with explanations like ‚Äúmanagement differences‚Äù (vchavcha.com) (essential-japan.com), leaving fans to speculate what really happened. Anycolor‚Äôs sudden firing of Selen mid-leave was particularly poorly handled; Nijisanji‚Äôs official statement admitted they‚Äôd harassed her and her emergency contact while she was hospitalized after a suicidal attempt, further enraging the community. Many in VTubing now demand transparency: the lack of clear policy around terminations has seeded distrust. Leaked industry knowledge suggests VTuber contracts heavily favor agencies. Talents often give up rights to their avatars and have little recourse if they quit. This has drawn parallels to older idol industries, and fans worry over abuse of power. Demands for standardized talent protections and fairer contracts have grown louder in the wake of major graduations.Management and Culture Clashes: Some controversies seem to arise from friction between Japanese corporations and overseas talents. Both Hololive and Nijisanji have noted ‚Äúcultural differences between Japanese and non-Japanese work environments‚Äù as an issue (hololivetoday.com). Non-Japanese VTubers (especially in EN divisions) have at times felt unsupported or misunderstood by management. The NiJi EN division in particular collapsed largely amidst mismanagement allegations. Many English-speaking talents have left NiJi EN in the past year for new careers or indies (Zaion Lanza, Pomu, in addition to Selen). Fans interpret this exodus as evidence that ANYCOLOR lost the trust of its foreign talent.Heavy-Handed Fandom Policing: Cover Corp‚Äôs recent legal crackdown on fan posts (filing disclosure requests to unmask anonymous posters, as reported by their PR) (cover-corp.com) upset many community members. While intended to protect VTubers from harassment, critics saw it as bullying the community. ANYCOLOR likewise has been harsh on social media, one-finding and suspending fans for criticism. These actions, combined with perceived secrecy, have made supporters feel unwelcome. In effect, agencies seem more focused on controlling criticism than addressing the root causes of discontent.In sum, there‚Äôs a growing narrative that agencies have mismanaged or exploited their talents. The repeated emergence of similar issues ‚Äì sudden graduations, legal threats, and cultural clashes ‚Äì has convinced many fans that agency systems are fragile and not always in the talent‚Äôs best interest (polygon.com) (investing.com).Permanent Shift or Passing Phase?Is the rise of indie VTubing just a temporary reaction or a lasting industry realignment? The evidence points to a possible , but also to caution: A fundamental change is that fans now visibly assert loyalty to individuals over companies (hololivetoday.com). This ideological shift is likely enduring: once viewers recognize a person behind the avatar, they tend to follow that person wherever they go. Agencies used to cultivate brand loyalty (hololive vs. nijisanji, etc.), but the exodus of stars is fracturing that pattern. Companies may need to adapt by treating talent as more than disposable IP.Indie Viability and Precedent: The success stories above show that indie careers can rival corporate ones. When enough data points (like Dokibird, Nimi, Maid Mint, Sameko) demonstrate profitability and reach for indies, more talents and fans will believe it. This could lead to a reinforcing loop: the more big names prove they can go solo, the more other talents will consider it, potentially shrinking the agency pool. Faced with talent flight, agencies might respond by reforming. There are signs Cover and ANYCOLOR are experimenting with more flexible arrangements. For instance, Cover has allowed some graduated talents to get an ‚ÄúAffiliate‚Äù status, as a way to keep them engaged. ANYCOLOR promised changes for NiJi EN after Selen‚Äôs exit (though details remain scarce). If agencies can offer slightly better terms ‚Äì more freedom, better communication ‚Äì they might stabilize. But if profits decline because top earners leave, they‚Äôll have to make real changes. The VTuber boom may be entering a mature phase. Niche communities are fracturing, new platforms (like VR or Kick streams) are emerging, and competition is heating up. Markets often oscillate: after rapid expansion comes consolidation or correction. We may see smaller agencies fold (like ‚Äúproduction kawaii‚Äù or ‚Äúidol‚Äù) and the large ones refocus, or new models (like affiliation status) arise. However, unlike a flash-in-the-pan trend, VTubing has shown staying power across multiple years and geographies (see rise of Nijisanji China, India, etc.).Global and Technological Factors: Finally, VTubing is riding larger tech waves ‚Äì from more accessible AR/VR setups to AI-generated avatars. These trends favor more indie creators (easy avatar creation, generative tools) and could fuel sustained growth. Corporate VTubers may then face competition not only from human indies but also from AI-driven avatars., while the recent surge in indie VTubing owes much to current controversies, it taps into deeper shifts: fan loyalty to personalities and wider tech democratization. It‚Äôs likely not just a short-lived rebellion. However, agencies still have powerful infrastructure, and new talents will continue to emerge through both models. The future VTuber industry may be more mixed than ever ‚Äì a blend of polished corporate acts and scrappy independents, each learning from the other. If agencies can regain trust (perhaps by improving talent contracts and transparency), they may coexist with a vibrant indie scene. If not, we could see a where the most famous VTubers are largely self-managed, with agencies playing a supporting or niche role.
